statement.text: The CEAP classification is the internationally accepted standard for describing chronic venous disease, comprising Clinical (C0-C6), Etiologic (Ec, Ep, Es, En), Anatomic (As, Ap, Ad), and Pathophysiologic (Pr, Po, Pr,o, Pn) components.

explanation.intuition: CEAP provides a comprehensive, reproducible language for describing venous disease severity, cause, location, and mechanism, enabling standardized communication between clinicians and comparison across studies.
explanation.key_insight: The 'C' clinical component is most commonly used in practice, ranging from C0 (no visible signs) to C6 (active ulcer), with each level representing progressive disease severity that guides treatment decisions.
explanation.technical_details: The revised CEAP classification (2020) added modifiers for recurrent disease (r) and includes 18 anatomic segments. The basic CEAP uses highest C class plus descriptor, while advanced CEAP includes all components. Corona phlebectatica (ankle flare) was added as C4c. Each limb is classified independently.
common_misconceptions: Misconception: Higher C class always indicates more severe disease. Reality: C class describes the highest manifestation present, but a C3 (edema) patient may have worse symptoms than a C4 patient.
Misconception: CEAP measures symptoms. Reality: CEAP is purely objective; VCSS measures symptoms and severity.
Misconception: C6 is permanent. Reality: Healed ulcers become C5, and can recur to C6 (C6,r).

clinical_classes.C0: No visible or palpable signs of venous disease

diagnosis: Visual inspection and palpation for clinical class
Duplex ultrasound for anatomic and pathophysiologic components
History for etiology (prior DVT, family history, congenital)
treatment: C2: Conservative or intervention based on symptoms
C5-C6: Active treatment of underlying disease essential

definition.@value: A standardized classification system for chronic venous disorders that describes the Clinical manifestation, Etiologic factors, Anatomic distribution, and Pathophysiologic mechanisms of venous disease.

learning_objectives: Apply CEAP classification to describe chronic venous disease
Identify etiology, anatomy, and pathophysiology components
Use basic and advanced CEAP appropriately
clinical_pearls: Always specify 's' (symptomatic) or 'a' (asymptomatic) after C class
C4 is divided into a (pigmentation/eczema), b (lipodermatosclerosis/atrophie blanche), c (corona phlebectatica)
C5 patients need surveillance - 50% recurrence rate for ulcers
Document CEAP for each limb independently
